(1) All humans have black hair: AxM(x) & AxF(x, M(x)), where M(x) represents "x is a human" and F(x, M(x)) represents "x has black hair".

(3) No one has been to Jupiter: ~Ex(H(x)), where H(x) represents "x has been to Jupiter."

(4) Students studying in the United States are not necessarily Asian: ~(Ex(F(x) & G(x))) & Ex(F(x) â‡’ (~G(x) & H(x, M(x))), where F(x) represents "x studies in the United States", G(x) represents "x is Asian" and H(x, M(x)) represents "x is not Asian or x is studying in the United States."

To keep it simple and concise, I've presented the symbolization in a list format, where the first element represents the Universal quantification for all x (Ax, Ex etc.), the second element is for the existential quantification for some x (Ex etc.), and the last two elements represent the negation (typically using ~, but omitted here for simplicity) and conjunctions (usually represented with "&" containing two predicate symbols elaborated in the format P(x)) as mentioned in the logic rule instructions.

The given sentence is: "All genuine scientific theories are theories that have been tested by practice."

First, we apply Method C by performing overturning and conversion. The overtaken part is "All genuine scientific theories" and the transformed part is "theories that have been tested by practice are not genuine".

The new proposition in [[]] format is: [["not","theories","that","have","been","tested","by","practice","are","genuine"]]

Therefore, the result of executing Method C for "All genuine scientific theories are theories that have been tested by practice" is: [["not","theories","that","have","been","tested","by","practice","are","genuine"]]

[âˆ€Pâ†’M, âˆƒSâ†’Â¬M â‡’ âˆƒSâ†’Â¬P]

First, let's identify the relevant properties and objects in the given statements:

Properties/objects for propositions P and S:

âˆ’ âˆ€P (All individuals P)
âˆ’ âˆƒS (There exists an individual S)
âˆ’ âˆƒSâ†’Â¬M (If there exists an individual of S, then not-M holds for this individual S)
âˆ’ âˆƒSâ†’Â¬P (If there exists an individual of S, then not-P holds for this individual S)

Now, let's translate the logical statements into their syllogistic forms:

âˆ’ âˆ€Pâ‡’M â†’ "All individuals in class P imply that class M contains at least one member"
âˆ’ âˆƒSâ†’Â¬M â†’ "If there exists an individual of class S, then at least one member of class M is not in class S"
âˆ’ âˆƒSâ†’Â¬P â†’ "If there exists an individual of class S, then at least one member of class P is not in class S"

Notice that these statements do not match any of the Valid Moods in Figure I, II, or IV. Thus, we are considering Figure III with its corresponding Valid Moods.

Let's see the best-fitting mood match for the given statements:

âˆ´ S()P â†’ "If at least one member of class S and at least one member of class P exist, then at least one member of class P will not be in class S"

Fortunately, the most appropriate Mood for the given argument is EIO (Exemption, Improvement and Oppression, Inverted), which will help us revise the statements in the form they need to be:

âˆ’ âˆ€Pâ‡’M â†’ "All individuals in class P, if any, imply that at least one member of class M exists"
âˆ’ âˆƒSâ†’Â¬M â†’ "If at least one member of class S exists, then at least one member of class M is not in class S"
âˆ’ âˆƒSâ†’Â¬P â†’ "If at least one member of class S exists, then at least one member of class P is not in class S"

The statement corresponds to Figure III Mood EIO. So, the answer is:

[[III]; EIO]].

[[B/A/C/D]]

According to the truth modality logic formula 9, #!p â†’ !#p means if it is not possible that p, then it is necessarily not the case that #p (i.e., it is impossible for someone else to win if Xiao Lin is not going to win). Based on this reasoning, if we assume Xiao Lin will necessarily win the championship, we can infer that it is necessarily not the case that #Xiao Lin will win the championship (i.e., Xiao Lin will certainly win the championship). The other answers can be eliminated:

A: Xiao Lin will possibly win the championship, but if he will certainly win, then Xiao Lin will possibly win (but not necessarily). However, if Xiao Lin will possibly win, then #Xiao Lin may win (it is possible for someone else to win), and this contradicts the assumption that Xiao Lin will necessarily win (so, no, Xiao Lin will not possibly win the championship if he will certainly win).

C: Xiao Lin cannot win the championship is contradictory.

D: Similar reasoning to option A. Xiao Lin will never win the championship is contradictory if Xiao Lin will certainly win, as this assumption does not allow for an alternative possibility (i.e., #Xiao Lin will win the championship).

Each year, Chinese hybrid rice showed higher yield as compared to American rice varieties.)

[C(S, 3/10, 3/10*3/2), C(S, 5/12, 3/10*3/2)]

Explanation: 

1. In Region A, 90/100 respondents reported exercising daily, so `P(S, 90, 100)`.
2. In Region B, 75/150 respondents reported exercising daily, so `P(S, 75, 150)`.
3. We apply the C-Reasoning rule since both samples show a proportion of exercised individuals in their respective populations.
4. We derive the proportions of exercised individuals in each group by dividing the number of exercised individuals by the corresponding sample size: (3/10) for Region A and (5/12) for Region B.
5. By C-Reasoning rule, if two samples exhibit similar proportions in a certain attribute, we can infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar proportions of that attribute.
6. Hence, the symbolical representation is [C(S, 3/10, 5/12)] indicating these two samples exhibit similarities in the proportion of individuals exercising daily, suggesting that these two populations share similar proportions of exercised individuals. 

The final statement can be written as: "These two health surveys in Region A and Region B exhibit similarities in the proportion of daily exercisers, which may indicate that these two populations exhibit similar proportions of exercised individuals." represented as [C(S, 3/10, 5/12)]

The GB Paradox applies to the presented scenario, as it involves contradictory predictive conclusions from different inductive reasoning. Here's the answer in [[A/B/C]] format:

B. Reevaluate r_1, r_2, r_3. 

Based on the LS Paradox, when multiple hypotheses are reasonably accepted but their logical consequences contradict another reasonably accepted hypothesis, it is necessary to reassess the reasonableness of these hypotheses. In this case,if hypothesis r_4 contradicts r_3 and leads to a contradiction, we must reevaluate our original hypotheses r_1, r_2, and r_3.

The speaker is expressing a mental state of liking or appreciating that the plan is feasible, rather than committing to its truth, urging the listener to do something, committing to doing something in the future, or changed the state of reality through the speech act itself. Therefore, the answer is: [[D]] Expressives.

[A/B] The given statement conforms to the C* Principle (Speaker's Criterion: Do not let your statement be weaker in information than what your knowledge allows, unless a stronger statement conflicts with the Information Principle). Perhaps there's an inference of attribution, but the original statement doesn't involvestronger information that contradicts the purpose of communication, thus the baby crying in bed and the mother picking her up doesn't lead up to the stronger piece of information (the mother is the baby's mother). Therefore, the choice is A. C* Principle.

In the inference process based on the given statement,

* CQ1 does not apply because there is no "stronger" statement that contradicts the Information Principle
* CQ2 does not apply because the statement does not contradict a weaker statement or involve multiple contrast sets

The statement does not involve application of C% Principle, as the statement follows a conventional understanding of a baby crying in a bed and needing a mother's care, without a purpose of minimalizing or hiding information.

The statement does not involve the application of C! Principle as the longer expression "the mother is the baby's mother" is not unnecessary or marked, and the additional information adds clarity to the already established situation and intent - which is to connect the parent and the child in this scenario.

A. âš¯ Definition (The defined term, Nuclear energy, is a species concept that is entirely contained within the extension of Atomic energy. Atomic energy's extension is not entirely contained within the extension of Nuclear energy.) The definition above belongs to the âš¯ Definition. The definition states that "Nuclear energy, also known as atomic energy, refers to the energy released during nuclear reactions when the structure of atomic nuclei changes." This definition finds the genus concept of "atomic nuclei" and explains that the defined term, "nuclear energy," is a type of energy released during nuclear reactions in the atomic nuclei. The definition is in the form of "defined term = differentia + genus," where "differentia" refers to the structure of atomic nuclei and "genus" refers to energy released during nuclear reactions.

The text provided uses the E. Contra- Method to argue for the idea that many scientists made important inventions and creations during their prime years when their thinking was most agile. The Contra- Method indirectly confirms the truth of the original proposition (that many scientists made important discoveries during their prime years) by refuting the contrary proposition (that scientists make fewer important discoveries later in life). The text mentions several examples of scientists who made inventions and discoveries during their prime, and through negation, implies that the opposite proposition (that scientists make fewer important discoveries later in life) is untrue. Therefore, the answer is [[E/F]]. (The Elim- Method would eliminate other possibilities, whereas the Contra- Method refutes the contrary proposition.)

[G/H] The given reasoning violates both the IllTrans Method and the IncorrInf Method.

IllTrans Method: From 'âˆ€x (Sx â†’ Px)' (every S is P), we incorrectly infer 'âˆ€x (Px â†’ Sx)' (every P is S) instead of 'âˆ€x (Sx â†” Px)' (every S is equivalent to P).

IncorrInf Method: From 'âˆƒx (Sx âˆ§ Px)' (there exists an S that is P), we incorrectly infer 'âˆƒx (Sx âˆ§ Â¬Px)' (there exists an S that is not P), and vice versa. An invalid inference is made about propositions with existential quantifiers.

Therefore, the correct answer is G/H.
